channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghan Army’s Test Begins With Fight for Vital Highway
item.description: A week with Afghan troops safeguarding Highway 1 offers glimpses of a road war in which powerful leaders on all sides battle for control of Afghanistan’s crucial artery.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: After Winding Odyssey, Tibetan Texts Find Home in China
item.description: An American scholar’s trove of 12,000 Tibetan-language texts has a new home, a lavishly decorated library on the campus of the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A newly discovered volume of a Tibetan Buddhist sacred text being scanned at the E. Gene Smith Library in southwest China.

item.title: U.N. Panel Finds Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea
item.description: After a yearlong investigation, the panel said it found evidence of an array of offenses, including crimes against humanity, in a report that will be released on Monday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: A Ukraine City Spins Beyond the Government’s Reach
item.description: Lviv and the surrounding region have largely achieved what protesters in Kiev have been demanding since November: the end of the authority of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young masked men guarding the entrance to the Lviv Region State Administration. They seized the offices of the governor, Oleh Salo, and do not let him enter.

item.title: The Oddities of Olympic Park
item.description: The Sochi Games are either avidly catering to the West, and the United States in particular, or Russia has adopted American sports culture as its own.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID SEGAL
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The vast scale of Olympic Park in Sochi makes buildings appear closer than they are.

item.title: A Wild Ride: Navigating Sochi’s Games
item.description: Access to the Sochi Olympics’ outdoor venues, scattered along the slopes at various altitudes, is via a confusing system of buses, vans and cable cars.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: The gondola makes a pass over the Extreme Park in Krasnaya Polyana.

item.title: Lebanon Forms a Cabinet After 11 Months of Deadlock
item.description: The cabinet’s 24 members span the political spectrum, including Hezbollah, the militant Shiite organization, and its Western-backed foes.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Bahraini Protesters Clash With Police
item.description: Protesters in Bahrain’s capital city clashed with security forces on Saturday, sending tear gas into a major shopping mall and bringing activity on the capital’s streets to a standstill.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lens Blog: The World’s Best (Unaltered) Photos
item.description: World Press Photo announced the winners of its 2013 contest while its judges lamented the proliferation of digital alterations, which disqualified several top contenders.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: A cluster of countries in Central America — Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador — makes up one of the most violent regions in the world. In many cases, clothes that are found become the only means to identify victims, like this woman's clothing found at a sugar plantation in Apopa, San Salvador. She was 17 or 18 years old. First place, daily life stories.

item.title: Panama Says Freed North Korean Ship Set Sail for Cuba
item.description: A North Korean ship detained near the Panama Canal for smuggling Cuban weapons set sail for the Caribbean island on Saturday with most of its crew on board after it paid a fine, the government said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Mob Attacks More Than a Dozen Gay Men in Nigeria’s Capital
item.description: A mob attacked gay people in a neighborhood in Abuja, Nigeria, beating them with whips and nail-studded clubs. When four victims were dragged to a nearby police station, police officers also beat them.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Chinese Ask Kerry to Help Tear Down a Firewall
item.description: Meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry, a group of Chinese bloggers appealed to the United States to take up the cause of Internet freedom.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: After Second Round of Syria Talks, No Agreement Even on How to Negotiate
item.description: The United Nations mediator for Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up the second round of peace talks on Saturday without breaking a longstanding deadlock or setting a date for a third round.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the United Nations negotiator on Syria, said at a news conference that the talks had ended without progress.

item.title: Spying by N.S.A. Ally Entangled U.S. Law Firm
item.description: A top-secret document, obtained by the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden, shows that an American law firm was monitored while representing a foreign government in trade disputes with the United States.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN and LAURA POITRAS
item.media:description: The Indonesian Embassy in Washington, left, and the building where Mayer Brown has an office. Indonesia retained the American law firm for help in trade talks.

item.title: Ugandan President Says He Will Sign Tough Antigay Measure
item.description: President Yoweri Museveni moved forward with a bill that would criminalize the promotion or recognition of homosexual relations.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: President Yoweri Museveni delayed signing a version of the bill last year, saying it was flawed.

item.title: A Debate Becomes a Brawl as Turkey’s Parliament Votes to Rein In Courts
item.description: Turkey’s Parliament met through the night, Friday into Saturday, and passed a controversial new bill that gives the government greater control over the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: The lawmaker Ali Ihsan Kokturk, after a bill expanding government control over the judiciary started a fight in Turkey’s Parliament on Saturday.

item.title: Prototype: At the Ready, at the Sochi Games
item.description: A company is poised to evacuate athletes of the United States Ski and Snowboard Association who are competing at the Olympics, whether for medical or security reasons.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE MARTIN
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Richards founded Global Rescue in 2004.

item.title: Applied Science: Small Business, Joining a Parade of Outsourcing
item.description: By using online job marketplaces to handle specific projects, companies of any size may be redistributing income toward lower-income countries, a research paper says.
item.dc:creator: By PHYLLIS KORKKI

item.title: Off the Shelf: The Case for Swapping Roles With China
item.description: A new book by Stephen Roach says it’s time for the United States to be more of a producer and for China to be more of a consumer.
item.dc:creator: By FRED ANDREWS
item.media:description: The author Stephen Roach says that unless the United States and China find a new way to prosper jointly, the alternative could be a devastating trade war that nobody wants.

item.title: Obama Promises New Aid to Jordan in Refugee Crisis
item.description: The president announced the economic package during a meeting in Rancho Mirage, Calif., with King Abdullah II of Jordan.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH WHEATON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: South China Sea Tensions a Backdrop to Kerry’s China Visit
item.description: Chinese officials take exception to statements by a U.S. Navy admiral that Washington would fulfill its obligations under a mutual defense treaty to help the Philippines if it came under attack
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: 2 Companies to Destroy Chemicals in Syria’s Arsenal
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons chose hazardous-waste disposal companies based in the United States and Finland.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Medicines Made in India Set Off Safety Worries
item.description: India, the second-largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Ranbaxy, one of India’s biggest drug manufacturers, pleaded guilty to felony charges and paid a $500 million fine last year.

item.title: Trade Pact With Asia Faces Imposing Hurdle: Midterm Politics
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. acknowledged that Congress will not grant President Obama fast-track trade promotion authority, which analysts call critical for deals with Asia and Europe.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Representative Nancy Pelosi on Friday at the Democratic Issues Conference in Cambridge, Md.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Political Star Rises on Vow to Upend Italy’s Old Order
item.description: Matteo Renzi engineered the Italian prime minister’s removal and is poised to succeed him, but now he faces the challenge of shaking the country out of its malaise.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: “This road is more difficult, rather than waiting for a slow attrition, because putting myself on the line now has an element of personal risk,” says Matteo Renzi, who is poised to become Italy's youngest prime minister.
